doc.ContractDescription: NORTHERN EURASIA IS CHARACTERIZED BY LARGE CARBON STORAGES AND SEASONAL FLUXES, THROUGH BOTH SINKS AND SOURCES, AND IS THOUGHT TO BE PARTICULARLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO CLIMATIC CHANGE. IN RECENT DECADES THE REGION HAS EXPERIENCED WARMING AND ATTENDANT CHANGE IN CARBON CYCLING, WITH FURTHER ALTERATIONS LIKELY TO CONVEY POSITIVE FEEDBACKS TO GLOBAL GREENHOUSE GAS FORCING. THE CARBON CYCLE OF THE ARCTIC DRAINAGE REGION OF NORTHERN EURASIA IS TIGHTLY LINKED WITH SURFACE WATER AND PERMAFROST DYNAMICS THAT, IN TURN, ARE INFLUENCED BY THE EXTENSIVE NETWORK OF LAKES AND WETLANDS ACROSS THE REGION. WE PROPOSE TO SYNTHESIZE THE RESULTS OF RECENT PROJECTS, FOCUSED ON THE CARBON CYCLING OF THE ARCTIC BASIN DRAINING THE NORTH EURASIAN EARTH SCIENCE PARTNERSHIP INITIATIVE (NEESPI) REGION, WITHIN A SET OF LINKED MODELS TO ESTIMATE THE MAGNITUDE, POTENTIAL FUTURE CHANGES, AND ASSOCIATED UNCERTAINTIES IN CARBON SINKS AND SOURCES. THE MODELING CONSTRUCTS CENTRAL TO THIS PROJECT HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED TO SIMULATE CH4 EMISSIONS FROM SOURCES SUCH LAKES AND WETLANDS, AS WELL AS OTHER CO2 SOURCES/SINKS. THEY ALSO LEVERAGE REMOTE SENSING DATA FOR CHARACTERIZATION OF SURFACE WATER AND FOREST/BOREAL DYNAMICS. LAKE METHANE EMISSION DATA AND SATELLITE-DERIVED NET PRIMARY PRODUCTION, BOTH TO BE DRAWN FROM RECENT PROJECTS, WILL BE USED IN A SYNTHESIS ANALYSIS OF THE REGION'S CARBON CYCLE AND FOR INTEGRATION WITHIN THE MODELING FRAMEWORK. FIELDS DERIVED FROM REMOTE SENSING FROM AMSR-E, MODIS, QUIKSCAT AND LANDSAT SATELLITES INCLUDE THE INUNDATION WATER FRACTIONS, LANDCOVER TYPE, AND NET PRIMARY PRODUCTION. A UNIQUE ASPECT OF OUR MODELING SYNTHESIS AND INTEGRATION CENTERS ON THE USE OF THESE REMOTE SENSING DATA TO CAPTURE KEY WATER AND CARBON CYCLE PROCESSES OPERATING ON RELATIVELY FINE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES. THE OVERARCHING GOALS OF THE STUDY INCLUDE QUANTIFYING CARBON CYCLE DYNAMICS FROM THE TERRESTRIAL LAND SURFACE, ESTIMATING THE POTENTIAL ASSOCIATED RESPONSES TO CONTINUED WARMING, AND GAINING AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE CONTROLLING PHYSICAL PROCESSES GOVERNING THE REGIONS CARBON CYCLES.
doc.MajorAgency: SYNTHESIS AND INTEGRATION OF RECENT RESEARCH CHARA
doc.MajorFundingAgency: SYNTHESIS AND INTEGRATION OF RECENT RESEARCH CHARA

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE A TWO YEAR PROGRAM TO DEVELOP ADJUSTABLE, FULL SHELL, ELECTROFORMED METAL GRAZING INCIDENCE X-RAY OPTICS. OUR TECHNOLOGY IS COMPOSED OF AN ARRAY OF ELECTRO-STRICTIVE ACTUATORS THAT ARE USED TO MOUNT THE INNERMOST SHELL OF THE TELESCOPE TO AN INNER REACTION STRUCTURE. THE ADJUSTERS ARE ENERGIZED ONCE UPON ASSEMBLY AND ALIGNMENT, AND ARE USED TO ALIGN THE SHELL S MIRRORS, AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, TO CORRECT LOW ORDER AXIAL AND AZIMUTHAL FIGURE ERROR. THE STRAIN DIRECTION OF THE ADJUSTERS IS RADIAL. OUR GOAL IS TO CORRECT THE FIGURE OF CURRENT TECHNOLOGY ELECTROFORMED METAL SHELLS WITH 10 TO 15 ARC SECOND IMAGING PERFORMANCE, TO THE LEVEL OF 3 TO 5 ARC SECONDS. ONCE THE SHELL IS ALIGNED AND FIGURE CORRECTED, VOLTAGE CAN BE REMOVED FROM THE ACTUATORS AND THEY MAINTAIN THEIR DIMENSIONS. THE NEXT LAYER OF ACTUATORS ARE THEN GLUED TO THE OUTSIDE (BACK) SURFACE OF THE MOUNTED MIRROR SHELL, AND THE NEXT OUTER SHELL GLUED TO THE ACTUATORS AND THE ALIGNMENT AND FIGURE CORRECTION PROCESS IS REPEATED FOR THAT SHELL. THIS PROCESS IS REPEATED UNTIL THE FULL ENSEMBLE OF MIRROR SHELLS HAVE BEEN MOUNTED AND THEIR FIGURE EACH INDIVIDUALLY CORRECTED. PRIOR DEVELOPMENT USING FLAT MIRRORS AND FINITE ELEMENT MODELING TO SIMULATE CORRECTION OF CONICAL MIRROR SHELL FIGURE ERRORS PLACES THIS TECHNOLOGY AT TRL 3. IT IS THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM TO ADVANCE THE READINESS LEVEL TO TRL 5 IN A TWO STEP PROCESS. WE WILL FIRST DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO MOUNT A SINGLE CONICAL SHELL TO A REACTION STRUCTURE, AND VERIFY THAT WE CAN APPROPRIATELY CORRECT FIGURE. THIS RESULT WILL BE CONFIRMED VIA X-RAY TESTING AT THE MSFC STRAYLIGHT FACILITY, AND WILL CONSTITUTE TRL 4 AND THE FIRST OF OUR TECHNOLOGY MILESTONES. WE WILL THEN ADVANCE THE TECHNOLOGY TO ALIGN AND MOUNT TWO NESTED MIRROR SHELLS, AGAIN CONFIRMING OPTICAL AND MECHANICAL METROLOGY WITH X-RAY TESTS. SUCCESSFULLY ACHIEVING 5 ARC SECOND IMAGING FOR TWO MIRROR SHELLS WILL CONSTITUTE TRL 5. THE IMPORTANCE OF THIS TECHNOLOGY IS TWOFOLD. ONE, IT WILL ADVANCE THE STATE OF THE ART FOR ELECTROFORMED METAL GRAZING INCIDENCE OPTICS, WHERE DEPOSITION STRESSES LIMIT PERFORMANCE. TWO, THE COMBINATION OF FIGURE CORRECTION AND MOUNTING ENABLES A LOW COST MEANS TO CONSTRUCT LOW MASS, MODERATE AREA, AND ARC SECOND IMAGING, WIDE FIELD OF VIEW SURVEY TELESCOPES. THESE INSTRUMENTS ARE CRITICAL FOR STUDYING LARGE AREAS OF THE UNIVERSE, AND ALSO IMPORTANT AS TOOLS TO SELECT THE MOST INTERESTING OBSERVATIONS FOR NARROW FIELD, HIGH ANGULAR AND HIGH SPECTRAL RESOLUTION INSTRUMENTS.
doc.MajorAgency: 3 TO 5 ARC SECOND FULL SHELL METAL X-RAY OPTICS
doc.MajorFundingAgency: 3 TO 5 ARC SECOND FULL SHELL METAL X-RAY OPTICS

6680: LIQUID AND GAS FLOW, LIQUID LEVEL, AND MECHANICAL MOTION MEASURING INSTRUMENTS

doc.ContractDescription: THE MARTIAN CRUSTAL DICHOTOMY IS THE OLDEST SURFACE FEATURE ON THE PLANET. THE ORIGIN OF THIS FUNDAMENTAL FEATURE ON MARS REMAINS UNKNOWN, AND TWO GENERAL HYPOTHESES ARE PROPOSED: FORMATION FROM A GIANT IMPACT EVENT OR FORMATION FROM DEGREE-ONE MANTLE CONVECTION. IN 2008, THE SINGLE IMPACT HYPOTHESIS WAS REVIVED BY (I) INFERENCE OF AN ELLIPTICAL SHAPE FOR THE PROPOSED BOREALIS IMPACT BASIN THAT DEFINES THE NORTHERN LOWLANDS AND (II) HYDROCODE SIMULATIONS PRODUCING A BOREALIS SIZE AND SHAPE FEATURE FOR A RANGE OF IMPACT PARAMETERS LIKELY TO BE ENCOUNTERED IN THE EARLY SOLAR SYSTEM. HOWEVER, THE PREVIOUS IMPACT SIMULATIONS DID NOT INCLUDE IMPORTANT ASPECTS OF THE PROBLEM: SHEAR STRENGTH IN THE MANTLE, PARTIAL MELTING, AND A CRUSTAL LAYER. PRELIMINARY WORK PRESENTED HERE INDICATES THAT SHEAR HEATING AND PARTIAL MELTING ARE BOTH IMPORTANT FACTORS IN DETERMINING THE AMOUNT OF MELT FROM AN IMPACT EVENT. THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO ANSWER THESE QUESTIONS: IF A SINGLE GIANT IMPACT FORMED THE BOREALIS BASIN ON EARLY MARS, WHAT GEOCHEMICAL AND SHOCK SIGNATURES SHOULD BE OBSERVED? IS THERE A SMOKING GUN OBSERVATION THAT WOULD STRONGLY SUPPORT OR REFUTE AN IMPACT ORIGIN FOR THE CRUSTAL DICHOTOMY? PROPOSED WORK. WE WILL: (1) CONDUCT SHOCK WAVE EXPERIMENTS ON MANTLE MINERALS AND ROCKS TO GATHER FUNDAMENTAL EQUATION OF STATE INFORMATION TO SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE THE THERMODYNAMICS IN NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS. (2) IMPLEMENT NEW AND SELF-CONSISTENT RHEOLOGICAL MODELS AND MELTING CALCULATIONS FOR THE MANTLE. (3) CONDUCT THE FIRST NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS OF BOREALIS-TYPE IMPACT EVENTS THAT INCLUDE MATERIAL STRENGTH AND A CRUST. (4) FOR VARYING IMPACT AND TARGET CONDITIONS, CALCULATE THE DISTRIBUTION AND MASS OF MELT, CRUSTAL EXCAVATION, CRUSTAL SHOCK DISTRIBUTION, AND PROJECTILE MIXING INTO THE MANTLE AND CRUST. (5) EVALUATE THE CONSISTENCY OF THE SIMULATION RESULTS WITH GEOPHYSICAL AND GEOCHEMICAL OBSERVATIONS OF MARS. EXPECTED RESULTS. THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE REALISTIC SIMULATIONS OF A BOREALIS SCALE IMPACT EVENT ON MARS THAT CAN ADDRESS THE VIABILITY OF THIS PROPOSED MECHANISM FOR THE FORMATION OF A CRUSTAL DICHOTOMY. THIS STUDY WILL DETERMINE IF IMPACT SOLUTIONS EXIST THAT SIMULTANEOUSLY AGREE WITH MULTIPLE OBSERVATIONS, INCLUDING (1) DIRECT FORMATION OF THE CRUSTAL DICHOTOMY (EXCAVATION OF ORIGINAL CRUST AND GENERATION OF LESS NEW CRUST FROM THE MELTED MANTLE), (2) PRESERVATION OF CRUSTAL REMANENT MAGNETIZATION IN THE SURVIVING CRUST, (3) GEOCHEMICAL DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THE CRUST IN THE DIFFERENT HEMISPHERES, AND (4) GENERATION OR CONTRIBUTION TO DISTINCT CHEMICAL RESERVOIRS IN THE MANTLE. WE WILL IDENTIFY ANY SIGNATURES OF A GIANT IMPACT THAT MUST HOLD TRUE IN ORDER TO LOOK FOR POSSIBLE TESTS OF AN EXOGENIC FORMATION OF THE CRUSTAL DICHOTOMY. THE RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY ARE NECESSARY TO ASSESS THE EFFECTS OF A GIANT IMPACT ON THE EARLY EVOLUTION OF THE MARTIAN CRUST AND MANTLE. THE SIMULATION RESULTS WILL BE BROADLY APPLICABLE TO STUDIES OF THE THERMAL EVOLUTION, CONVECTIVE PATTERNS IN THE MANTLE, AND EFFECTS OF GIANT IMPACTS ON THE DYNAMO. THIS WORK SUPPORTS THE MARS FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH PROGRAM BY CONDUCTING STATE OF THE ART EXPERIMENTAL AND COMPUTATIONAL STUDIES OF IMPACT CONDITIONS ENCOUNTERED ON EARLY MARS. THIS WORK DIRECTLY ADDRESSES MEPAG 2008 INVESTIGATION III-A-10 TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTS OF LARGE SCALE IMPACTS ON THE EVOLUTION OF THE MARTIAN CRUST.
doc.ParentRecipientOrCompanyName: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE
